headline.main: Weak Job Market Leaves City's Unemployment Rate Flat

docs.abstract: A school bus strike and Wall Street layoffs contributed to the weak market last month and kept New York City’s unemployment rate well above the nation’s, the State Labor Department reported.
docs.snippet: A school bus strike and Wall Street layoffs contributed to the weak market last month and kept New York City’s unemployment rate well above the nation’s, the State Labor Department reported.

headline.main: The Costs of Emergency Room Cost-Cutting

docs.abstract: Proposals to cut health care costs often focus on emergency rooms. But basing reimbursement on discharge diagnoses is a bad idea, a new study found.
docs.snippet: Proposals to cut health care costs often focus on emergency rooms. But basing reimbursement on discharge diagnoses is a bad idea, a new study found.

headline.seo: Tennessee Governor Balks at Medicaid Expansion
headline.main: Governor of Tennessee Joins Peers Refusing Medicaid Plan
headline.print_headline: Governor of Tennessee Joins Peers Refusing Medicaid Plan

docs.abstract: Gov Bill Haslam of Tennessee says he will not expand Medicaid in his state as called for in the federal health care overhaul, joining 18 other Republican governors who have rejected expansion for now.
docs.snippet: Gov. Bill Haslam, a Republican, said he instead wanted to use federal money to buy private insurance for as many as 175,000 low-income residents.

docs.lead_paragraph: Recent radiology graduates with huge medical school debts are having trouble finding work, let alone the $400,000 jobs that beckoned as they signed on for years of low-paid labor as trainees.

headline.seo: Trainees in Radiology and Other Specialties See Dream Jobs Disappearing
headline.main: Job Prospects Are Dimming for Radiology Trainees
headline.print_headline: Job Prospects Dimming for Radiology Trainees

docs.abstract: Radiologists still make twice as much as family doctors, but are high on list of specialists whose incomes are in steepest decline; radiology graduates with huge medical school debts are having trouble finding work, let alone the $400,000-and-up dream jobs that beckoned as they signed on for five to seven years of relatively low-paid labor as trainees.
docs.snippet: Recent radiology graduates with huge medical school debts are having trouble finding work, let alone the $400,000 jobs that beckoned as they signed on for years of low-paid labor as trainees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Moroccan government spends more than $5 billion a year on health care, but public hospitals are decrepit and lack doctors, equipment and medicine.

headline.seo: Fewer Than 30 Percent of Moroccans Have Health Insurance
headline.main: Morocco's Health Care System in Distress
headline.print_headline: Morocco's Health Care System in Distress

docs.snippet: The Moroccan government spends more than $5 billion a year on health care, but public hospitals are decrepit and lack doctors, equipment and medicine.

docs.lead_paragraph:
Last week, we published a case study about Baked in the Sun , a wholesale bakery and distributor that is trying to decide how best to comply with the Affordable Care Act. Starting in January, the new law requires businesses with 50 or more full-time employees to offer health insurance or pay a penalty. Owned by Rachel Shein and Steve Pilarski, husband and wife, the company employs nearly 100 workers to bake and deliver freshly made pastries to coffee shops, hospitals and hotels in Southern California.
 
Baked in the Sun has offered health insurance to its employees in the past but many are young and healthy and have preferred to keep more money in their paycheck, rather than contribute to a health plan. Soon, though, almost all workers will have to carry health insurance — through their employer, a government exchange or other source — or pay a penalty. And, as the case study discussed, Ms. Shein and Mr. Pilaski are trying to decide whether they will offer health insurance, pay a penalty or outsource enough work that they can reduce their head count below 50 and be exempt from the law.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s top health care adviser acknowledged on Tuesday that costs could rise in the individual health insurance market because of provisions of the landmark health care law.

headline.seo: Health Official Acknowledges That Costs May Rise
headline.main: Health Official Acknowledges That Costs May Rise
headline.print_headline: Health Official Acknowledges That Costs May Rise

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Kathleen Sebelius acknowledges that costs could rise in the individual health insurance market, especially for men and younger people, due to provisions in 2010 health care measure that eliminate discriminatory market practices that have imposed higher rates on women, people with medical problems and older people.
docs.snippet: President Obama’s top health care adviser acknowledged on Tuesday that costs could rise in the individual health insurance market because of provisions of the landmark health care law.
